sections.title: What is the passive?
sections.content:
In an **active** sentence the subject does the action: **The dog bit the man.**

In a **passive** sentence the object of the action becomes the subject, and we focus on what happened rather than who did it: **The man was bitten by the dog.**

We form the passive with **be + past participle**:
• Present simple: The letter **is written** by the secretary.
• Past simple: The letter **was written** yesterday.
• Present perfect: The letter **has been written**.
• Future (will): The letter **will be written** tomorrow.
• Modals: The letter **can be written** / **must be sent**.

sections.title: When do we use the passive?
sections.content:
We use the passive when:

• **The agent (who did it) is unknown or unimportant:**
  – My bike was stolen. (We don't know who stole it.)
  – English is spoken all over the world. (We're not focusing on who speaks it.)

• **We want to focus on the action or the object:**
  – The new hospital was opened last year. (We care about the hospital, not who opened it.)
  – The report has been finished. (We care that it's done.)

• **In formal or academic writing:**
  – The experiment was carried out in a controlled environment.
  – It is believed that the situation will improve.

If we want to say who did the action we use **by + agent**: The window was broken **by the storm**.

sections.title: Form: be + past participle
sections.content:
The passive always uses a form of **be** (am, is, are, was, were, been, being) + **past participle** (e.g. written, done, taken, built).

**Tense** is shown by the form of **be**, not by the past participle:

• Present simple: am/is/are + past participle → The room **is cleaned** every day.
• Past simple: was/were + past participle → The room **was cleaned** yesterday.
• Present perfect: have/has been + past participle → The room **has been cleaned**.
• Past perfect: had been + past participle → The room **had been cleaned** before we arrived.
• Future: will be + past participle → The room **will be cleaned** tomorrow.
• With modals: modal + be + past participle → The room **must be cleaned** / **can be cleaned**.

sections.title: By-agent and other prepositions
sections.content:
We use **by** to introduce the agent (the doer):
• The play was written **by Shakespeare**.
• The building was designed **by a famous architect**.

We often **omit** the by-phrase when the agent is unknown, obvious or unimportant:
• He was arrested. (We know the police do this.)
• The meeting was postponed. (We don't need to say who did it.)

Some passive verbs take a different preposition (not by):
• I'm **interested in** this topic. (not *interested by)
• She was **surprised at** the result. (or by)
• The room was **filled with** balloons.
• He's **known for** his charity work.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• Passive = **be** (in the right tense) + **past participle**.
• Use passive when the agent is unknown, unimportant, or we want to focus on the action/object.
• Agent = **by** + noun (often omitted).
• Don't confuse tense: **was written** = past passive; **has been written** = present perfect passive.
• With modals: **can be done**, **must be sent**, **should be checked**.

sections.title: Typical learner errors
sections.content:
• **Wrong form:** Wrong: *The letter was send.* Right: **The letter was sent.** (Past participle, not base form.)
• **Wrong tense of be:** Wrong: *The building is built in 1990.* Right: **The building was built in 1990.** (Past → was/were + past participle.)
• **Using active instead of passive when the subject is the object of the action:** Wrong: *English speaks all over the world.* Right: **English is spoken all over the world.**
• **Adding an extra 'be' with modals:** Wrong: *It can be be done.* Right: **It can be done.** (Modal + be + past participle, only one 'be'.)

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
questions.explanation: Passive = was + past participle. Send → sent.

questions.question: Choose the correct passive form.

options.a: English is speak all over the world.
options.b: English speaks all over the world.
options.c: English is spoken all over the world.
options.d: English spoken all over the world.

questions.explanation: Passive: be + past participle. Speak → spoken.

questions.question: 'The building ____ in 1990.' Which fits?
questions.explanation: Past time (1990) → past passive: was/were + past participle.

questions.question: Which is correct with a modal?

options.b: The work must be done by someone.

questions.explanation: Modal + be + past participle. Done is the past participle of do.

questions.question: 'The report ____ yet.' (Present perfect passive)
questions.explanation: Present perfect passive: have/has been + past participle.

questions.question: The letter _____ (send) yesterday.
questions.explanation: Past passive: was + past participle (sent).

questions.question: English _____ (speak) in many countries.
questions.explanation: Present simple passive: is + spoken.

questions.question: The new hospital _____ (open) last year.
questions.explanation: Past passive: was + opened.

questions.question: The work _____ (already / do).
questions.explanation: Present perfect passive: has been + done.

questions.question: The room _____ (clean) every day.
questions.explanation: Present simple passive: is + cleaned.

questions.question: My bike _____ (steal) last week.
questions.explanation: Past passive: was + stolen (steal → stolen).

questions.question: The report _____ (must / finish) by Friday.
questions.explanation: Modal passive: must be + past participle.

questions.question: The play _____ (write) by Shakespeare.
questions.explanation: Past passive: was written. By + agent.

questions.question: The problem _____ (discuss) at the meeting tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Future passive: will be + discussed.

questions.question: This book _____ (read) by millions of people.
questions.explanation: Present perfect or present simple passive: has been read / is read.

questions.question: The window _____ (break) by the storm.
questions.explanation: Past passive: was + broken. By + agent.

questions.question: The documents _____ (can / find) on the server.
questions.explanation: Modal passive: can be + found (find → found).

questions.question: Wrong: 'The letter was send yesterday.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Passive needs past participle: send → sent.

questions.question: Wrong: 'English is speak all over the world.' Correct the sentence.
answers: English is spoken all over the world.
English is spoken all over the world
questions.explanation: Passive: be + past participle (spoken).

questions.question: Wrong: 'The building is built in 1990.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Past time (1990) → past passive: was built.

questions.question: Wrong: 'The work must be done by someone.' (If you mean the work is necessary.) Correct to a natural passive.
questions.explanation: By someone is unnecessary; the passive alone is enough.

questions.question: Wrong: 'The report has not been finish yet.' Correct the sentence.
answers: The report has not been finished yet.
The report has not been finished yet
questions.explanation: Present perfect passive: have been + past participle (finished).

questions.question: Wrong: 'He was arrest by the police.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He was arrested by the police.
He was arrested by the police
questions.explanation: Passive: was + past participle (arrested).

questions.question: Wrong: 'It can be do tomorrow.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Modal passive: can be + past participle (done).

questions.question: Wrong: 'The meeting was postpone.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Passive: was + past participle (postponed).
